reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s move to a cardinal, vNM-representable value function (and the implicit commensurability this suggests). If that move were illegitimate, parts of the ‘mostly-great’/‘90% of value’ framing and some quantitative narrow-target claims would weaken, so centrality is moderate. However, the paper largely argues fragility “on many views” without needing a single shared metric across religions/communism/etc., and it explicitly restricts Section 3 to complete vNM-style views while acknowledging that not all moral views fit; so the critique overstates how much the argument ‘quietly assumes’ cross-doctrine commensurability, limiting strength. Relevance is low-to-moderate because Forethought treats expected-value-style cardinalisation as a Tier 1 methodological commitment; unless backed by a novel route to decision-relevance under incomparability, this is close to questioning settled ground.
title: The paper conflates moral pluralism with commensurable value dimensions
